Research, Typeface Design

Designing a Serif Typeface for Modern Editorial Use

Problem

Serif typefaces contain fine details - thin strokes, thin hairlines and short serifs, that become indistinguishable or disappear when displayed in smaller sizes, especially on low resolution screens and printed content in poor quality. As a result, sans-serif fonts are often preferred in text content.

Despite this, serif fonts offer distinct advantages. The small serifs used at the ends of a character lead the reader’s eye, improving readability. Serif fonts also hold historical and aesthetic associations related to authenticity and professionalism.

Category of Serif Typefaces

Humanist and Transitional Serifs: These styles are great for long form text, but the strong contrast between the thick and thin strokes lead to legibility problems in smaller sizes.

Slab Serif: This style of type has lost the feeling of history present in other serif typefaces. The serifs are large and thick, making it hard to read when in smaller sizes. These fonts are typically bold and grab the viewer’s attention, making it great for titles, logos, and other display purposes rather than for body text content.

Problem Statement

{/* Right Column */}

How might I design an a serif-typeface that adheres to the conventions tied to serif type while improving the legibility for small digital and editorial text content, expanding the use of serif fonts in modern contexts and offering more ways to convey character and expression?

Design Process

What are the rules that define a serif typeface?
  • Small strokes attached to the letters
  • Contrast between thick and thin strokes
  • Smooth transitions between the letter stroke and the edges of the serifs
Each individual typeface character also has it’s own rules, but I won’t expand on that here.

What are opportunities that can edit a serif typeface to make it more legible?

The first characters I worked on were lowercase hamburgefonstiv, as they covered the most rules and could be referenced with creating the other letters.

  1. Amount of contrast between thick and thin strokes
  2. Size of the serifs
  3. Thickness of the serifs
  4. Openness of the arches
These characters were then printed to note the quality and legibility of each variation.

With this knowledge, the letterforms were adjusted and the rest of the characters were designed based on these characters.

Reading Test - Times New Roman vs Arial vs My Font

To validate the benefit of the final typeface, I needed to conduct a study on reading legibility. I tested ten participants reading speed for passages of text in three different typefaces at 10px size.

On average, reading my typeface was 700 milliseconds quicker, with 5/10 participants completing the passage in my typeface faster than the other two.

The Reflection

With heavy serifs, thicker overall stroke weight and less contrast between thick and thin, Quanne is a perfect typeface for small font sizes.

It was a great project for me to combine research and practicality with learning how to design complex letterforms that each adhere to design conventions. As I reflect further on my experience in typeface design, I realize that there is always room for growth and improvement. Although I am proud of my progress, I know that next time I revisit this project, I will notice additional areas that could benefit from more attention and refinement.
